campaign.story:
Designed for gamers, streamers, families, game stores and libraries, and anyone who loves playing games with others, Gameboard-1 merges physical and digital tabletop gaming to enhance your play and let everyone focus on what matters: having a great time! 
Gameboard-1 is a technology device and a platform that will change the way we play games together -- a device to teach new players faster, digitize set-up and scorekeeping, access an unlimited-play game library and allow users to try new games before they buy... all while maintaining the crucial physicality between players and pieces! 
 Patented Sense Screen — interact directly with real physical gaming pieces, any shape or size, as many as the board can fit, with or without batteries
 Smart pieces – read data directly from your game pieces (like D&D character stats!)
 Mobile control – control and interact with the board directly from your mobile device
 Four-hour battery – take your game on the road, then plug back in for non-stop play
 Wireless sync with other boards – automatically connect for a larger table
 Game library – buy and own individual games, or subscribe for everything!
Created uniquely for gamers, this gaming console is larger than an iPad, more interactive than a television, and easier to carry than your game shelf. 
The Gameboard-1 is a beautiful 16” x 16” sense screen hardware device that is thin, lightweight, and portable.
From the beginning, our development process has focused on implementing functions that allow multiple styles of game play, alone or with others.  
Our technology recognizes inputs from multiple sources simultaneously, from several fingers to a game piece that holds its position after being placed on the board.
Physical pieces can interact with the Gameboard-1 through id tags that store up to 2k of encrypted data including the location, orientation, and type of piece as well as user data, such as a character's hit points or experience. Ten (10) generic bases will be provided as part of rewards that include a Gameboard-1 unit. Games can also be played with purely digital pieces. 
Our display refresh rate allows fast-paced gameplay with low latency, from multiple contact points, when using physical or digital objects. 
We've also designed the Gameboard-1 to connect to your personal electronic device for private screen game play or augmented reality applications.
WIFI and Bluetooth integration allows personal electronic devices to create virtual interactions with the board environment, with or without internet access.
To increase screen real estate, the Gameboard-1 can even connect multiple gameboards for a multi-screen gaming experience, using NFC sensors and internal antenna arrays to make wireless connection seamless and fast.
Connecting multiple Gameboard-1 units is a snap! (This image is a render to illustrate multiple-board functions.)
Gorgeous hardware isn't enough. We're gamers and we know what we want: more games! 
This campaign will help us finish building a single marketplace that will offer thousands of individual titles a la carte and an optional monthly subscription service for unlimited access to that vast library of games and gaming tools. 
It's like Netflix for games, including everything from classics like chess and checkers to modern strategy games to interactive and original creations from partner game creators, with networked game play similar to PSN or Xbox Live.
We are building partnerships with some of the biggest names in the hobby and gaming industry to create a robust library... and we're excited to reveal more partners over the course of this campaign.  
We want anyone to be able to bring their games to the platform. Our open developer SDK means that it is simple for developers to add and update their games in the ever-expanding games library.The Last Gameboard marketplace isn't restricted to board games. Developers can make any game or content they want: from purely digital board games to games that interact with physical pieces, cards, and dice in ways we haven't even imagined yet.
We don't take the term "Partners" lightly.  We provide GitHub, Architect and Engineer access to help drive innovation and product roadmap.  We are building a community. We are the community.   
The Last Gameboard technology is fully compatible with Unity and Unreal.
The Developer Edition includes everything you need to start creating your own games, programs, and innovations for this platform.   
Gameboard-1 is beautifully designed from the inside out. It's a sleek console with real world game play informing every element of design. 
We have our prototype in the lab right now and cannot wait to share the first unit from the manufacturer in the coming weeks!    
Here are just some of the hardware features we plan to include with every Gameboard-1 unit we ship:
The Gameboard-1 is designed with thin edges to maximize playable surface area, chemically strengthened glass and a plastic housing designed for durability.
The 1920x1920 LCD display exceeds the specification for high-definition, so that every detail is crisp and clear.
Plus, at only five pounds, the device remains lightweight and portable. The on-board battery allows up to four hours of game play, so the game can continue by candlelight if the power goes out.
 Two USB-C ports support not only peripheral devices, but with a USB-C to HDMI adapter you can output the contents of the screen to another device, making Gameboard-1 perfect for Twitch and YouTube streamers who want to embed or overlay the game within Wirecast or OBS.
Play online with networked play, or download your game and enable the Gameboard-1 local WIFI network to connect private screens and peripherals when offline.
Four speakers and microphones let sound become an integral part of your game play, while WIFI and Bluetooth connectivity makes syncing with your personal mobile device a breeze.
An onboard 64 GB eMMC hard drive stores your key files locally, while a 64-bit CPU and 4GB of RAM keep everything running smoothly on our custom-built The Last Gameboard OS (TLGOS).
FAMILIES:  From your living room to visiting grandparents, now your entire game library can travel with you. Enjoy a family game with the kids, then stay up late with the latest strategy game.
GAMERS: Thanks to full compatibility with D20Pro, now included in your subscription, gamemasters can direct the action with every tool available in a multi-player virtual tabletop... on a real tabletop! Interactive maps, combat management, and access to tabletop systems—from Dungeons & Dragons to Pathfinder and beyond—make Gameboard-1 a crucial part of your weekly campaign.
GAME STORES: Immediately demo many of the games on your shelves for customers, helping to increase sales, then bring out Gameboard-1 again for open game night. Game stores are all about community and The Last Gameboard helps you focus on creating the extraordinary experiences that keep bringing regulars back to the table.
STREAMERS: An essential tool for tabletop streamers, Gameboard-1 lets you bring the details straight to your online audience. Forget trying to set up an extra camera above the table and lighting the board properly: now you can display partial or full game AV output right inside your favorite streaming software, while you focus on the interactive play that your audience loves.
DEVELOPERS: Whether you're adapting your classic board game for TLGOS or creating an innovative new experience that merges tabletop with the unique capabilities of Gameboard-1, you're at the cutting edge of new technology, bringing games to a new generation of gamers.    
We've designed Gameboard-1 with the following technical specifications that we intend to meet or exceed in manufacturing:   
A successful Kickstarter is just the first step in the process of bringing the Gameboard-1 to your door! 
Following the Kickstarter we will prepare and launch surveys on BackerKit, where you will be able to manage your pledge, update your shipping address, and where we will charge market prices for shipping and fulfillment. Please DO NOT add money for shipping during the Kickstarter, so that we can keep those costs as accurate as possible for each pledge level prior to shipping.
We are excited to use BackerKit for pledge management, where you will be able to select add-ons, update your shipping address, pay fair market prices for shipping, and track the status of your rewards.  
 The initial development of Gameboard-1 was funded thanks to a seed round of private capital, which allowed us to complete design of our prototype and finalize our manufacturing partnerships. Now we're bringing Gameboard-1 to Kickstarter to raise money to fund:
Manufacturing Testing (including beta boards)
The Manufacturing Run
Packaging
Gameboard-1 Case Development
With your help we'll be able to transition our product from prototype to retail-ready.
Most importantly, this limited-edition Kickstarter helps bring together the core community of gamers, streamers, and developers who will receive first access to the Gameboard-1.  
About the Company
In 2018, avid hobby gamer Shail Mehta met with hardware guru Rob Wyatt over beer to discuss the fundamental flaw with touchscreen devices: why couldn’t any digital device recognize physical objects for varying shapes and sizes, especially the types of objects that are needed for hobby gaming.
Gameboard-1 was born out of the need to address the analog problems of hobby games while maintaining the essence of why gamers love to play. Gameboard-1 solves the problems of set-up/take down, learning/teaching new games, inability to explore games before buying, games that cannot be easily saved, finding someone to play with and much more.
In January 2019, The Last Gameboard, Inc., was formed. They began to establish relationships with game makers all around the world, incorporating both Unity & Unreal to bring the best hobby gaming content to TLG’s upcoming platform.  
Shail Metha - CEO / Co-Founder
Shail has a passion for gaming. When she immigrated to the US in the 90s, Shail encountered a group of children in her apartment that were playing chutes and ladders. Shail, not knowing English, just began to play. The role of gameplay in creating community and fostering human connection has been central to Shail’s work at The Last Gameboard.
In her professional life, Shail has a financial background working for hedge funds and venture capital funds. She has consulted for the Nuclear Regulatory Committee, City University of New York, City & County of Denver ‘s projects, and Triunity Engineering. Has managed teams and executed projects throughout her career. Shail is the driving force for the vision and future for The Last Gameboard.
Rob Wyatt - CTO / Co-Founder
Rob moved from the UK to the US nearly 20 years ago. Known as the “Guru of Hardware” in the industry, Rob loves creating new technologies in gaming and is an avid skydiver. He was the system architect of Microsoft’s Xbox console and went on to work at Playstation, Atari and Magic Leap. Ron owns several patents in AR/VR including a patent on multiple app sparse pixel time warp in AR headsets and processing. He is a visionary, designer and maker of The Last Gameboard’s incredible technology.
 Dustin Hatchett - Business Development
Dustin has been an avid gamer since he first played TSR’s Boot Hill and FASA’s Star Trek RPG in 1983. In his 25 years in the gaming industry, Dustin has managed multiple retail game stores in Denver, Colorado and owns a production company producing live action role-playing games and multiple game conventions. For the past 20 years, he has worked in technical and project management roles for large telecommunications companies.
Dustin will bring his extensive game industry knowledge and background in project management as co-owner of Rocky Mountain Games (a pre-visualization and development company) to The Last Gameboard as Business Development Coordinator.
Mike Horn - Advisor
Mike is a recent inductee into the Pop Culture Hall of Fame who grew up in the collectibles business. After college, his first job was as a buyer for Diamond Comic Distributors, the world’s largest wholesaler of comic books and supplier to thousands of comics and hobby shops. His job was to line up and buy trading cards (initially) and later all licensed merchandise.
In 1994, he left Diamond to form his first company, Palisades Marketing. Originally a marketing consulting agency, he evolved it to become a leading manufacturer of licensed collectibles. By 2005, Mike had grown Palisades to nearly $7 Million in annual revenue with 20 full time employees. Afterwards, Mike formed SwagDog and Power Up Factory, two successful ventures in the collectibles industry, before returning to consulting with the formation of Golden Strategic Development in 2019.
 Lys Galati - Marketing
Elysabeth “Lys” Galati was seven years old when she finished reading the leather-bound silver foil edition of Frank Miller’s The Dark Knight Returns. Still overwhelmed by the book, her mother asked “Lys, your math is getting better. Do you want to come up with the adults and play D&D?”. Nothing was the same after that. A simple game night became an origin story.
After a stint with Diamond Comics doing everything from customer service to buyer, Lys saw a gap in the industry. Lots of incredibly creative people who put their heart and soul into products who often didn’t have the time and (sometimes) skills to promote themselves properly. Sphinx Public Relations started in 2000 and has been an ongoing business ever since. The company was founded on the idea that all geek voices, regardless of budget, deserved a chance at the spotlight.  
Get Your Project Funded Today!

campaign.story:
What is Gods and Masters?
Gods and Masters is a pen-and-paper role playing game setting for the award-winning Savage Worlds system. It is a game of urban guerrilla fantasy, and players choose one of three factions.
The Gronman Empire is the official power in the city. They have large numbers of soldiers, reinforcements on call at all times, and the legal authority to arrest and imprison their enemies.
The Nacaraj is a “shadow army,” made of warriors from the local population who loathe foreign oppressors and foreign gods. They cannot beat their enemies in a full-on war, so they ambush, assassinate, and kidnap the invaders, in the hopes of liberating their homeland.   
The Church of Leshnah is a powerful vampiric cult that draws on the inequality in imperial society to recruit new members. Leshnites have used the political turmoil to infest the city and prey on its inhabitants.
For a taste of the Gods and Masters, see our free JumpStart, which features seven pregenerated imperial characters and their mission to shut down a black market arms dealer that goes terribly wrong.
As of the first update after launch, backers of the Raider level and beyond will have access to the beta of the player's guide and faction guides. It will be missing the cover, table of contents, some of the art, and so forth, but the beta version will be totally playable.
 How is Gods and Masters unique? Do I really need another fantasy game? 
Gods and Masters is certainly fantasy, but it was not inspired by pastoral European history or traditional fantasy tropes. We drew our inspiration from the urban guerrilla conflicts of the last century. Dokaro is a city controlled by legionaries, war drakes and winged dragoons instead of riflemen, tanks, and helicopters. But the setting has more in common with the Battle of Fallujah or the Spanish Civil War than any conventional fantasy setting. Dokaro's soldiers, partisans, and religious fanatics are all armed to the teeth and ready to spill blood in their war for control, with civilians caught helplessly in the middle.
The faction system provides a totally separate game feel for characters on each side of the conflict. Each faction receives its own gear, Edges, Hindrances, and a host of other unique bonuses. None of the factions will play the same, and each promise their own individual game experience.
The natives of Dokaro have an established tradition of necromancy in their culture. They use reanimated creatures and warriors in their struggle for independence.
Though ferocious and able to turn the tide of a skirmish, drakes and other beast mounts are not easily directed. Beast riders are constantly at risk of losing control of their creatures, and being thrown from their saddles, attacked, or eaten.
Many game masters want to know how much a new setting will offer to their existing campaigns. Besides the new Edges, Hindrances, and gear, the following features and mechanics from Gods and Masters will be especially useful in many Savage Worlds settings:
Interrogation Rules
The Interrogation mechanic provides a means for player characters to extract information from NPCs. While the skills of the interrogator are paramount, there is no surefire way to guarantee that all the information they get is totally reliable. 
Likewise, player characters who are imprisoned and facing interrogation will have to rely on their iron will to keep from breaking an spilling their secrets. However, clever characters have at least a small chance of giving some false information to their captors. 
Dramatic Stealth
Dramatic Stealth is a subsystem in the same vein as Dramatic Tasks or the Chase Rules from Savage Worlds. Dramatic Stealth provides characters with a mechanic for sneaking around heavily guarded areas, in order to infiltrate enemy bases, assassinate foes, or abduct hostages. As the heroes slither through the shadows, any careless or clumsy actions can raise the alertness of the nearby guards, and eventually lead to some characters losing their cover and being attacked by swarms of enemies. 
Elemental Magic
The elemental magic system of G&M provides mages with a selection of elements with which to imbue their powers. Each as its own power modifiers, providing some advantages and disadvantages in different tactical situations. 
Arcane Background (Occult)
G&M includes three faction-specific arcane backgrounds. The most unique and generally applicable for other settings is the Arcane Background (Occult). The occult is far more accessible and powerful than other magical paths. It requires no special bloodline, nor do characters need to follow a moral path. This black magic is fueled by incalculably old beings with no care for petty human constructs  such as morality. As long as their devotees are willing to pay for their power with sacrifices, the ancient masters are happy to oblige. 
Most of Gods and Masters is set in the urban environments of Dokaro. Nonetheless, PCs will encounter some of the savage creatures that inhabit the surrounding jungles from time to time.
 Why are we using Savage Worlds?  
Savage Worlds is the best rule system for Gods and Masters. It allows for fast, dynamic combat, and unique non-combat situations and encounters. The rules are streamlined enough for game masters to improvise and create their own scenarios and encounters without getting bogged down in stats and figures, but crunchy enough to give tactical gamers an interesting challenge, all while keeping the story moving.
Gods and Masters is compatible with the Savage Worlds Adventure Edition, the newest version of the Savage Worlds rules. The creators have been playing Savage Worlds for over a decade, and understand the rules well. And since it was designed from the ground up with this rule system in mind, there will be no clunky translations from other systems.
This game references the Savage Worlds game system, available from Pinnacle Entertainment Group at www.peginc.com. Pinnacle makes no representation or warranty as to the quality, viability, or suitability for purpose of this product.

After the Kickstarter campaign is concluded and the book is finished, Gods and Masters will be sold online through DriveThruRPG.com, as a PDF and in hard copies with the print-on-demand option. The setting includes the following features:
Full color layout and artwork 
An expanded gear list that makes fights more strategic and tactical
A new playable species, the reptilian anir, divided into three races
Fire, Earth, and Water Anir are the gods' favored creations, blessed with longevity, natural weapons, and elemental immunities. It is only through the benevolence of their rulers, the immortal Elders, that humans have been granted equal legal standing.
Five species of exotic beast mounts (with multiple subspecies), from the burrowing Sandsquirmer drake to the nimble Demonhorn kirin
Setting rules for Interrogation and Dramatic Stealth
An expanded list of power modifiers, to give each form of elemental magic its own unique kicks and limitations
Three playable factions, each with their own Advantages, Disadvantages, unique gear, Arcane Background, and goals, providing a totally individual game play experience for each side of the Dokaran conflict
Various sections of the book are emblazoned with a color-coded banner on the right page for easy reference. The general parts of the Player's Guide and Master's Guide are brown, while the Faction sections and Savage Tales sport red for the Imperials, green for the Nacarajin, and purple for the Leshnites. Even the sidebars and tables are colored to match.
A full set of Edges and Hindrances for the Corruption, a disease that can gradually turn mundane humans into predatory vampires
Ten gritty Savage Tales, at least six of which are compatible with each faction
The Master’s Challenge: An optional difficulty mode for experienced and tactically-minded players
An adventure generator and reputation system that rewards character success and punishes failure with a variety of social and legal consequences
A bestiary with a dozen creatures that infest the wilds around Dokaro
A selection of NPCs, providing plenty of enemies for every faction to fight
A Rogue’s Gallery of heroes and villains in each faction

Author: J.C. Thompson
J.C. has been a Savage Worlds GM for 10 years, ever since his friends first introduced him to Deadlands. In that time, he has run several campaigns with his weekly game groups, and hosted Savage Worlds games in conventions across the United States. J.C. has always held a strong interest in the insurgent conflicts of the last century,  and he used this interest to shape Gods and Masters into what it is. 
J.C. is the founder and owner of Twitchy Butcher Studios LLC, and Gods and Masters is his first major publication. 
Editor: Tommy Brownell
Tommy Brownell is the editor for Gods and Masters. In addition to editing duties for multiple Savage Worlds licensees, including Daring Entertainment, Savage Mojo and Gun Metal Games, he has also written for Pinnacle's Savage Tales of Horror Vol. 2 and Gun Metal Games' Forces of Light. In addition to his freelance work, he brings a decade's worth of experience in running Savage Worlds in a variety of campaigns, both published and homebrew, to this project.
Layout Designer: Thomas Shook
After playing other RPGs for several years starting in his teens, Thomas stumbled across Savage Worlds, fell in love with it instantly, and it became his go to system. Following several conversations with Shane, Thomas joined Pinnacle Entertainment Group as an editor and layout designer. He has worked on several products including: Lankhmar, Rippers, Weird Wars I, RIFTS®, and several other lines.
In addition to working with Pinnacle, Thomas has had the honor of working with other companies in the game industry including Gun Metal Games, Sigil, Modiphius, and GRAmel. When not working on various projects Thomas enjoys spending time at the beach with his kids after relocating to Australia from the States.
Artistic Team: TaniMetal Studio
TaniMetal Studio is an art studio based in Indonesia. Founded in 2011 as AM Project Studio, the team has produced drawings and paintings for comics, games, and movie posters. They have spearheaded the artistic development of Gods and Masters, and created the vast majority of the artwork for it. 
Contact Us
Want to contact us outside of Kickstarter? Visit our website, and fill out the contact form. We will get back to you as soon as possible. You can also like our Facebook page, to learn about the newest announcements and see some of our latest art as it comes out. 
 How do I get a print copy?
We are a small publishing company, and this is our first major product. Ordering a print run of books is just not financially feasible right now. If you do want a printed copy, the print-on-demand feature at DriveThruRPG should accommodate you after the crowdfunding campaign is over. For those who wish to order a printed book now, see our Hero reward level, for a print-on-demand voucher.
If you want to get the book printed yourself for your personal use, we grant you unambiguous permission to do so on the first page, so hopefully print shops won’t give you any trouble. If they do, send us an email and we will try to sort things out with the printer.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Gods and Masters is nearing the final stages of its development. The major challenges for the core PDF are mostly behind us. As mentioned above, the layout and artwork are already mostly complete (save for a couple pictures that need coloring), and the book is very playable right now. We will be releasing the beta of the full PDF to all our backers within a couple of days after the Kickstarter payment clears.

We will spend a month after release updating any flaws that we missed during the editing process, and responding to customer feedback. Roughly one to three months after the crowdfunding is over, we will release the final, updated PDF to all our backers, and put it on DriveThruRPG for retail sale.

Barring the untimely deaths of several of our project creators, this book will come out very soon. We have contingency plans for just that occasion, too.

The only real challenges we could potentially face are in meeting the stretch goals. We currently have an excellent team of artists, designers, and writers, and we could find others if we ever needed to. We will keep you updated if the stretch goal release dates change.

We will try to answer questions at least once a day while the crowdfunding campaign is going on, and at least twice a week once it is over. We will try our best not to fall behind on this, but all of us have other jobs, so there may be an occasional delay.

updates.update_content:
Hi everyone, 
I think this will be the very last update. I put together some pregenerated characters for the Nacarajin, and decided to release them for free on DriveThru, as a thanks for funding the Kickstarter. You can find them here.
Good gaming, everyone.

Hi everyone,
I just sent out copies of the last stretch goal to all backers of the appropriate levels. This last release, Death in the Dark, features two longer scenarios by veteran Savage Worlds licensee Charles White. 
I know this last Stretch Goal is a bit behind schedule. I apologize for that. Charles had nothing to do with it; he sent me his text in a very prompt fashion. The blame lies entirely with me. It has been an interesting and exhausting year, as I'm sure y'all know quite well. I was also experiencing some creative burnout after getting the main book out the door.

Hi everyone! 
Gods and Masters is now available in print! If you pledged $25 or more, you should have gotten email from DriveThruRPG just now, allowing you to print at cost. I provided a hardcover and softcover link to everyone, so you have your choice of either (or both). I am also updating the PDF files for the last time. As mentioned before, any further updates will be corrected in an errata page sometime in the future.

Hi everyone, 
It seems like time for another update. 
We received the first copy of the print version, but there were a couple things that didn't look right, so we are ordering new proof copies, and should be able to make them public by mid-February. I apologize for the slight delay. We also caught a couple errors, so the books will have some typos and stat blocks fixed. Any further important errors that we see will be updated in a printable errata sheet sometime down the line. Thank you to everyone who noticed and reported problems so far.

Hi everyone, 
We just have a quick update for tonight. The print edition for G&M has been uploaded to DriveThruRPG, and is currently going through their premedia preparation phase. We hope to make the PoD option public very soon. 
Meanwhile, our last guest author has finished the first draft of his second adventure, and the cover of the last stretch goal is currently being colored. Should have that to you by February.

campaign.story:
LET'S PLAY tells the little-known stories of inmates and former inmates who go to great lengths to play table top role-playing games like Dungeons & Dragons behind bars. They handcraft twenty-sided dice, build their own campaigns from scratch, even wage legal battles against the United States prison system to assert their right to play.
For decades, role-playing games like D&D and Pathfinder have been banned in many United States prisons. Some wardens claim these games are demonic and foster fantasies of escape.
Yet even when books and dice are banned, incarcerated players have found creative workarounds. They band together to battle monsters and overcome obstacles, in virtual worlds as well as real life.
Inmates say these games are rehabilitative and are helping them prepare for life on the outside.  Recent research studies agree: Cooperative gaming builds skills like teamwork, critical thinking, and creativity.  Even more importantly, games like D&D bridge racial divides. In California, the gaming table is one of the only places where prisoners of different races and gang affiliations set aside their differences to do something cooperatively.
LET'S PLAY is told primarily from the perspective of inmates who have waged legal battles for the right to engage in gaming rehab. Some lost; others--like Kevin--changed the system forever.
Handmade prison D20
For eight years, Kevin battled the California Department of Corrections. It all started when he returned to his cell to discover that his gaming materials had disappeared, including hundreds of pages of handwritten campaigns and elaborate maps that adorned his cell from floor-to-ceiling. 
During Kevin's jury trial, the legendary creator of Dungeons & Dragons, Gary Gygax himself, flew out to testify on his behalf.
Excerpt from Gary Gygax's letter to Kevin after the trial.
Thanks to Kevin's lawsuit, role-playing games are now an official activity at several California prisons. But the battle is not yet over. Though Kevin won the lawsuit and the right to play, his novels, maps, and campaigns were never returned to him. Do they still exist in the basement of some courthouse? We want to find out.
Through the story of the lawsuit and the players, like Kevin, who were impacted by it, LET’S PLAY aims to get to the root of the national controversy around role-playing games in America’s prisons and explore philosophical questions around inmates rights, the rehabilitative potential of role-playing games, and the purpose of the criminal justice system.
Finally, LET'S PLAY is a film about perspective and identity… about using role-playing to see the world through the perspective of different characters and building empathy.
                                                                           >>>-<<<
PERSPECTIVES FROM THE PLAYERS ON WHY ROLE-PLAYING GAMES ARE SO IMPORTANT IN PRISON...
"We were hardcore. We’d play from soon as we got back from breakfast to lockup. Saturday or Sunday—all day long." - Mark, former inmate, California 
"We used to run underground games with no books or anything. It was pretty L33t." - Melvin, Inmate, Colorado
"Rehabilitation in the Department of Corrections is structured in a way that gives no alternatives. Not everybody is built the same. Dungeons & Dragons is my rehabilitation that I can deal with to escape into my own reality to solve my own problems." - Aaron, former inmate, Colorado
"Our rules are no evil characters, no leaving the team behind. Selfish players will usually die." - Carlos, Inmate, California
"Prisons are the most segregated places in the world. The D&D table is one of the few places where you can have blacks and whites playing together without fear of reprisal." - Jared, Founder, Prisoner Reentry Network
"It became more than just Dungeons & Dragons at that point. It started that way, but it became about the first amendment in prisons." - Kevin, former inmate, California
                                                                        >>>-<<<
A.K.A... HOW MY CAREER DEVELOPING CRIME SHOWS CAME TO INTERSECT WITH MY LOVE OF D&D
The creator and brainchild of LET'S PLAY, Elisabeth de Kleer, brings to the table(top) over ten years of production experience in the 'true crime' genre. While directing shows for CBS, Netflix, National Geographic, the BBC, VICE, and the Discovery Channel, Elisabeth has interviewed hundreds of inmates in prisons across the united states.
An interview at a maximum security prison in Texas.
When not investigating cold cases or interviewing inmates, Elisabeth can be found at the gaming table or writing articles about the rehabilitative impact of role-playing. Some of you may have already come across one of her articles in VICE:
Dragons in the Department of Corrections
How Inmates Play Tabletop RPG's in Prison where Dice are Contraband
Or the following award-winning documentary she produced for VICE in 2017 about a couple cellmates in Colorado who played together both inside and outside of prison.
Elisabeth has also partnered with a San Francisco-based organization called the Prisoner Reentery Network that is using gaming as tool to help recently-released inmates reintegrate into society. This is where she met Kevin and uncovered the story of his lawsuit against the Department of Corrections. 
A beautiful piece that was filmed by ABC News on this group.
However, while her articles and short film have brought attention to the topic, Elisabeth believes a longer form documentary is the best way to do justice to this controversial topic.
Over the last couple years, Elisabeth and her team have filmed dozens of interviews with inmates and former inmates who have played role-playing games at prisons across the country. So far this film has been self-funded, which is why we need your support. Here are some of the ways your money will be used to help us finish the film:
 Fees for accessing and copying legal materials related to D&D cases. This will allow us to take a deep dive into some of the most interesting lawsuits, like Kevin's, and attempt to  track down the gaming materials that were confiscated from him.
 Cost of putting together a professional camera crew so we can film gaming groups inside prison. (We've already done the most difficult part, which is getting soft approval to film in the first place. Now we just need funding to make the most of this special opportunity.)
 Funds for hiring an animator to breathe life into hand-drawn inmate fantasy art and to create a visual style for the film. The art will be used to illustrate the story in a way that weaves together magical elements with real life. For example, the warden of the prison might be depicted as a dragon or “boss” and the prison itself, a dragon’s lair. These visual intersections of gameplay and real life show how the game becomes a platform to express and explore their inner struggles and demons.
Creating a marketing and distribution plan that will promote both the film as well as recreational therapy behind bars.
With $60,000, we believe we can create a short film that takes a deep dive into one of the most interesting prisoner rights cases in history, but it will be tight. Each additional dollar we raise makes it possible to include additional content and improve the production quality of the film so that it can compete against the Hollywood heavy-hitters at film festivals around the world. If necessary, film grants (which are very difficult to obtain during pre-production but much easier when the film is nearing completion) are also an option we're considering for down the road if expenses surpass the money we raise through crowdfunding.
To bring this project to life, we've put together an awesome team of filmmakers, gamers, and experts.
And we're partnering with the following organizations...
 Hawke Robinson, a Department of Health Registered Recreational Therapist, founder of RPG Therapeutics LLC http://www.rpgtherapy.com/ and RPG Research  https://www.rpgresearch.com/, uses role-playing games like Dungeons & Dragons, Doctor Who, No Thank You Evil, and others as tools for rehabilitation.  He has been researching the effects of RPGs on participants since around 1985, and developing programs using RPGs in all formats (tabletop, LARP, computer-based, and solo) to achieve educational and therapeutic goals for various populations since 2004. When he's not lecturing and teaching workshops on gaming-as-therapy, you can find Hawke driving around the country in an RPG gaming bus.
Hawke Robinson will serve as an on-camera expert and advisor to the film.
The Prisoner Reentry Network, founded by attorney Jared Rudolph, is an Oakland-based nonprofit that supports successful transitions from incarceration to the community. Jared works as a trial lawyer at the San Francisco Office of the Public Defender, and regularly speaks about mass incarceration and its history. Every other weekend, he runs a Dungeons & Dragons game called “Second Life” to help recently released inmates build community and reintegrate into society.
Jared Rudolph and the Prisoner Reentry Network will be featured on-camera, and Jared Rudolph will serve as a criminal justice advisor to the film.
A PRN-facilitated "Second Life" game in San Francisco.
Kanaka Endeavors is a 2D20 gaming system developed by Danny, an inmate in the California Department of Corrections. Danny has been testing the system with his gaming group behind bars as well as players on the outside and hopes to roll it out when he's released from prison in 2019. 
Danny will be featured on-camera and Kanaka Endeavors will help fulfill some of the crowdfunding rewards.
Danny and the other D&D players pictured in an article entitled "Nerds United" that Danny wrote for the prison newspaper.
Music for the Kickstarter video was provided by: https://www.bensound.com/royalty-free-music 
FINALLY...
If you can't help us monetarily, please help us by spreading the word through social media. The more people know about this documentary, the better we can get the word out about the rehabilitative potential of role-playing games in prison.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
By far, our biggest hurdle is getting on-going access to film games behind bars.

Getting IN to prison is harder than one might expect. Both state and federal facilities have extensive rules for media visits. Additional staff must be brought in to accompany the production crew. Some states prohibit cameras entirely.

Fortunately, Elisabeth de Kleer has extensive experience navigating prison media rules. Over the last 10 years, she has filmed at dozens of maximum security prisons around the country (primarily for Discovery Channel shows) and developed relationships with the administrative staff that approve filming requests.

While we've received soft permission to film games we've been following at a couple different prisons, where we ultimately film will depend on how much access we are given. The ideal scenario would be one where we'd film a game over the course of many months, following the trials and tribulations of the inmates both as characters inside the game and in real life. To do that, we need to show the administrators that we have enough of an audience to warrant the additional time and effort on their end to host us, as well as to pay our professional film crew for their time.

Put simply, the more backers and funding we have, the better our chances of getting prolonged access to some of the subjects of our film.

updates.update_content:
Hello, fellow players and supporters! We are moments away from reaching the final 48 hours of our campaign. Thank you for standing by us over the course of the last month. Your ongoing support, personal stories you've shared with us, and enthusiastic feedback affirms our belief that this project has the power to make an impact. Thank you.
We are now two days away from the end - close enough to have a realistic idea of where the campaign stands and to start doing some self-reflecting. While the love this project has received has been inspiring, we've raised only half of what we'd need to carry it out. Our chances of being funded are very slim indeed.
After much reflection and several consultations with crowdfunding experts, we've come to realize that the campaign would have had a better chance of succeeding with more pre-launch promotion and a stronger social media presence. A couple naysayers have also told us the topic is too 'niche' to capture the attention of a large audience. We don't agree. The themes of empathy, identity, and the purpose of the criminal justice system affect all of us, whether we are amongst the estimated , or not. We believe that if we retool the campaign, double-down on the pre-launch promotion, and build our social media presence, we can easily blow past the $60K minimum to bring this worthy documentary to fruition. In other words, we want to leave the doors open for the possibility of a relaunch.

I've tried not to bombard you with loads of updates, but it's the final nail-biting week of the campaign and we wanted to let you know what we've been up to. Last weekend, our Advisor Hawke Robinson and his research team were out in force at Gen Con in Indiana sharing news about the project and listening to dozens of gamers share their own stories of playing RPG's behind bars. Meanwhile, the San Francisco team held down the fort at our home base, attending panel discussions at the Gen Con Berkeley Pop Up and doing podcasts. 
And people are starting to take notice!

Thanks to the generous support of all of you who share our fascination with this wacky, beautiful, inspiring story of gaming-as-rehabilitation. The men featured in this documentary have gone to great lengths to bring light and creativity to some of the darkest dungeonous corners of our country - and it's helping them prepare for life on the outside. campaign.story:
JUST ADDED!
Thanks to volunteers we will be able to do Crash Course episodes of ETU, Deadlands, Rippers, and Savage Rifts if we hit our minimum goal in addition to our core episodes. 

Not everyone learns easiest by reading and currently the only tutorial videos for Savage Worlds are long and broad. New and perspective players tend to feel overwhelmed by an hour long video and those looking to just brush up on a single mechanic don't want to sit through an entire explanation of the system in hopes of a video covering what they need.  Games like Dungeons & Dragons have seen growth by leaps and bounds thanks to embracing multiple forms of education will well produced, highly polished, and easily digestible online educational content. Savage Worlds for Beginners aims to do the same and will be a 15 episode series designed both for new players and those looking to brush up on less used rules.  Each episode will only be 10-15 minutes and cover a very specific portion of the rules such as chases or social conflicts.  Backers to our Kickstarter will get access to exclusive items as well as the ability to purchase the entire season for download to view online, offline, or even share with curious gamers.  Together we hope to help the Savage Worlds community grow even larger and bring even more new players and GMs into the fold while also providing a useful tool for those that might need to brush up from time to time. 
Learn Savage Worlds, One Video at a Time
If you're new to the Savage Worlds game system, or just looking to brush up on a few rules, this is the Kickstarter for you! Our goal is to produce a 15 episode series of 10-15 minute episodes, each dedicated to a different aspect of learning the Savage Worlds sysyem. The thing is, proper production isn't cheap, and if we want something worth sharing all over the community to get even more people interested in playing, we need to have the professional polish the gaming community has come to expect!

"This game references the Savage Worlds game system, available from Pinnacle Entertainment Group at www.peginc.com. Savage Worlds and all associated logos and trademarks are copyrights of Pinnacle Entertainment Group. Used with permission. Pinnacle makes no representation or warranty as to the quality, viability, or suitability for purpose of this product. "
You might be wondering, "I have the book, why do I need videos to learn anything?" 
It's true, that's one way to learn a system, but not everyone learns best that way. Plus, you might just need a refresher on how chases work, or have a friend that wants to try out the game before investing the time and money on a book. Short videos have been proven to be a great tool for not only teaching the rules, but also spreading the popularity of a game.
Tabletop RPGs have a long history of being taught to new players by one experienced player, or the GM. The thing is…the biggest obstacle to growth of the hobby is a prospect player not having a friend that already knows the game. The hurdles to learn a game on your own are often just too much to handle. The explosion of already popular games such as Dungeons & Dragons owe a lot to the online communities that make easily accessible videos that teach only what a new player might need at any given time. This project aims to provide that same experience for Savage Worlds players, which currently is severely lacking.
Now that you know why making tutorial videos is important, you're probably wondering who we are and why WE should be the ones to do it.
If you are not familiar with our work, we are the people behind the YouTube channel known as The GM Table. In addition to making podcasts dedicated to Savage Worlds (such as SWADEcast), we also have been the first to break major news for the system, like when the writer of Savage Worlds, Shane Hensley, gave us an exclusive interview detailing many of  the products coming in the next year.  Our channel is already a trusted authority within the Savage Worlds community, with working relationships with many Savage publishers
 We also have done this before, with great success. When The GM Table first premiered, we had a show titled “Let's Run Savage Worlds”, which became the primary source for many new players to learn the system. But, having just started out, and not having any equipment, the quality wasn't always great. 
With the new edition of Savage Worlds coming out, we thought this would be the perfect time for a new take on learning Savage Worlds. Just as the new Adventure Edition took 15 years of experience, we're putting our experience to use and completely start from scratch on a polished, professional series. We currently have 15 episodes planned for our first season of “Savage Worlds for Beginners”. These are arranged to, step by step, introduce players into everything they might need to know to play a game. Starting with only the rules you’lol need to know if you’re given a pre-generated characters in a one-shot or con game, before advancing into the basics of character creation. We'll round everything off with the Chases Tutorial that more experienced players have been asking for for a long time. 
 We currently have 15 episodes planned for our first season of “Savage Worlds for Beginners”. These are arranged to, step by step, introduce players into everything they might need to know to play a game. We supply pre-generated characters so players can feel comfortable playing in a one-shot or con game, before advancing into the basics of character creation. We'll round everything off with the Chases Tutorial that more experienced players have been asking for for a long time. 

Episode List:
Episode 1: Savage Worlds Introduction: Will introduce the series to new viewers, give viewers an idea of what they will come to learn in the coming episodes, explain why Savage Worlds might be right for you, and introduce many of the characters in the series.
Episode 2: Getting Wild: In this episode, we will break down the basics of dice in Savage Worlds including TN4, the “Wild Die”, and “Acing”.
Episode 3: Your Attributes & You: In this episode we delve deeper into the different attribute scores, as well as the concept of dice size as level of ability.
Episode 4: Hard Core Skills: In this episode we will take the time to look at each of the different Core Skills and their uses.
Episode 5: One Roll to Rule Them All: In this episode we will start teaching the system in practice, with the Quick Encounter rules, including dangerous encounters, staged encounters, and networking.
Episode 6: Getting Social: In this episode we will discuss how social skills are used in Savage Worlds, as well as how Social Conflicts work.
Episode 7: Don't be Dramatic: In this episode we break down dramatic tasks and their many uses.
Episode 8: Wanna Fight About It?: In this episode we cover the basics of combat in Savage Worlds for initiative, parry, range, cover, tests and movement.
Episode 9: I've Been Hit: In this episode we cover the second half of combat, specifically taking damage, soaking, and wounds.
Episode 10: Patch It Up : In this episode we cover the basics of healing including the golden hour, healing checks, injuries, and walking wounded.
Episode 11: Powered Up: In this episode we cover the basics of powers, including arcane backgrounds, power points, and casting modifiers.
Episode 12: Watch for Hazards: In this episode we cover the many hazards in Savage Worlds as well as Fatigue.
Episode 13: It Builds Character: In this episode we begin looking at character creation with edges and hindrances.
Episode 14: My First character: In this episode we wrap up character creation with a step by step "Quick Character Process" that is designed to help new players not feel overwhelmed. 
Episode 15: Catch Me if You Can: In our Season Finale, we cover everything you need to know about the Chase rules. 

We hope that, at this point, we’ve piqued your interest in seeing our series dedicated to teaching Savage Worlds get made. In all honesty, we could make this series at a kitchen table with a cheap webcam and get the basic information across, but to really help Savage Worlds grow and spread, a professional looking product will go much further outside of our existing community. 
The problem is a professional product has professional costs including gear, a crew, and most importantly, insurance.  Below is a basic breakdown of the bare minimum costs to hire the services of a small crew, rent gear, and more.
Minimum Production Costs
Skeleton Crew: $1,000* 
Production Gear & Location Fees: $1,000*
Post Production: $2,000
Artist Fees: $500
Kickstarter, Website, & Swag Fulfillment: $1,000
Total: $5,000
*This cost is literally calling in favors and friendships while working off the books with personal, but professional, gear.
As you can see, even a small production adds up fast and this is the main reason we are doing this Kickstarter. While these videos will be free on YouTube for anyone in the gaming community to see, and we could run ads on them…we'll likely be dead of old age before we would even break even. Let alone being able to pay for everything up front!

It's a lot to ask to help fund something that anyone in the community will be able to see online for free once it's finished. That's why we are doing our best to offer some exclusive items only available to those that helped support this season.
The Wylde Button*: Show off your Savage Worlds support with a button of our mascot, “Wylde the Wild Die”!

The Wylde Tote*: We've done buttons for special guests and giveaways before, but never have we done a canvas tote bag. Big enough to carry all the essentials to your game table.
* Notice: As of right now, all physical rewards have shipping included for US backers  We are currently calculating the best costs for international backers.
 In addition to the 15 planned episodes we have options to either unlock or flat out purchase additional episodes called Crash Courses. When Savage Worlds Adventure Edition was first revealed, we created three episodes in an attempt to show off the basics of the system. Learning from that experience, we were able to plot out the 15 episode season that would actually do the system justice. But, we also realized that the crash course format could be best used to introduce players and GMs to different savage settings. In less than 15 minutes we will run down the basic pitch for a setting, what makes it special, and any key rules specific to that setting, all in the same style and humor of the core series. As you’ll see in the Stretch Goals below, we already have plans to feature  Deadlands and ETU in their own episodes, but we hope to unlock even more. 
 We want every penny we raise to go straight into making Savage Worlds content and experiences for the community. With that in mind,we have already plotted out some exciting stretch goals if we exceed our $5,500 goal. 
At $6,000 we will be able to get more props and, yes, even puppets for our episodes to add even more fun and humor to each episode.
At $7,000 we will make a Crash Course episode dedicated to the East Texas University setting.
At $8,000 we will also make a Crash Course episode dedicated to the flagship setting for Savage Worlds, Deadlands!
At $9,000 we can upgrade our crew and pay them their actual fees, not the costs they are charging for being friends from college, as well as go through the proper channels to rent better gear and insure all of it properly. 
At $10,000 we will take the crew to Genghis Con and have a “The GM Table” booth, where we will be giving out free swag to fans, as well as running Savage Worlds games specifically to teach people the system.
At $12,000 we will produce a documentary covering the history of Savage Worlds, it's impact on the gaming culture, and interviews with many people in the industry about their experiences with the system.
At $14,000…in addition to Genghis Con, the ”The GM Table” crew will also get a booth at ChupacabraCon, with even more free swag and tutorial games!
Starting at $15,000 and every thousand after we will produce another Crash Course episode, and will let backers vote on the setting!

One way or another, these episodes will be made. We are still working out the details about being able to have the season being downloadable so backers can burn them as a DVD, complete with menus and bonus features, but otherwise there is no real risk to speak of. If by some disaster we are unable to film in our given window, we will reschedule filming and inform our backers, but we have consistently put out videos on a weekly basis for nearly two years and counting.

updates.update_content:
So we didn’t hit our goal but that’s ok. I want to thank each of you for supporting us and let you know we’re already working on preproduction on the show figuring out what we can and can’t do. We are also reaching out to publishers both official ACEs and SWAG who may want to sponsor episodes. If you know someone with an rpg product that might be interested feel free to spear the word. Our current pricing is listed below:
$50 Shout Out $100 Shout Out, Product or Logo Image, and brief description $250 Full Crash Course episode on your product

We Aren’t Giving Up: We only have about 3 hours till this crazy experiment comes to an end one way or any other. First I want to say that we are NOT giving up on this in the final hours, but we are also preparing ourselves emotionally for if it doesn’t happen and that’s what we want to talk about here.
The Episodes WILL Be Made: If we do not reach our goal I want everyone to know that the episodes will still be made one way or another. We won’t be able to afford a professional crew or extra staff for post production, but that won’t stop us. Episodes will be slower to come out and won’t be as polished. We’ll shoot the entire series on a cell phone if that’s what we have to do and edit it on an iPad like many of our shows.

So we didn’t have International Shipping in any reward with a tote because we got screwed over by the person that was supposed to organize that for us. Since were in the final hours I decided to just bite the bullet do a flat $20 shipping and personally eat any additional cost myself, but now all tiers are open for international backers.

I just talked with some of my volunteer crew and IF we can hit out minimal funding they are willing to ab extra weekend of shooting and I'll cover the incidentials out of pocket. This means if we hit out goal on top of the 15 core episodes we will also film these extra episodes:
1) A Guide to Licensed Savage Settings.
2) ETU Crash Course

Hey all, I wanted to thank everyone from our first supporters to our newest. In the last half day we've seen a huge bump both from new supporters hopping on and existing supporters raising their pledges. We are less than 2k from our goal which is close enough that even a couple angel investors could put us over the top, but I'm not holding my breath on  that. Instead I'm going to keep pushing like I know many of you are to get as many people who have been unsure to make the leap with us and get the project in front of as many eyes as possible before the end. We can still do this!

updates.update_content: We are currently about 30 hours from the end the Kickstarter and while we still have $2500 to go we also have another 200 people that are following this project that haven’t yet backed. We can do it and we can make something the Savage Worlds community is severely lacking.

We are in the final hours of our Savage Worlds for Beginners Kickstarter. It’s now or never to help be part of a new era of growth for the Savage Worlds community and help both new and old players and GMs learn the latest edition of the game while getting exclusive swag!

This week we dedicated the Savage Worlds podcast I produce, “SWADEcast”, to getting new blood into the hobby which is the biggest reason we are attempting this Kickstarter
https://youtu.be/0u4KXN0Onc8

I don’t tend to like spelling out all the costs and technical aspects of producing a show, mostly because I doubt many RPG fans will really care about budget spread sheets. That said a YouTube channel I was privileged enough to be part of VERY early in my career did a video about budgets for music videos that I think does a great job at shining a light on just how much goes into even slightly professional productions. https://youtu.be/RL7LRzn_jH8

campaign.story:
Hi, we're Zombie Orpheus Entertainment. We make awesome movies and television shows, then we give them away.
We've been around since 2010 and we love our work, because our work is sponsored by YOU. Plus, we're thrilled that everyone is invited to share, remix, and tell totally new stories within our shared cinematic universes. 
When you support a ZOE show, you know that we're giving it straight back to the community. And you know that every fan will be welcomed, regardless of their ability to pledge. We make our stories for all of us and invite you to join one of the best fandoms in existence. 
Want to watch JourneyQuest? It's streaming for free, worldwide on The Fantasy Network!
Have Amazon Prime? Watch here in the US. Watch here in the UK.
PROJECT UPDATES

 MILESTONES REACHED 

At Zombie Orpheus Entertainment, we are a Fan-Supported, Creator-Distributed company. This means that our fans have the power to continue or cancel the story. We crowdfund through Kickstarter because it allows us to bypass the traditional studio system, ensuring that the stories we want to tell are not constrained by what Hollywood is willing to fund. Every JourneyQuest film is produced under the Shared Cinematic License Agreement which allows you to remix, create, adapt, and distribute works set in the world of Fartherall. These are films funded by you for you. 
Note that anything marked with "kickstarter exclusive" is an exclusive item for Kickstarter backers (or from other crowdfunding platforms), with remaining stock available through conventions and special promotions only.  
Take a moment to like and follow our social media and community accounts on the services you use (ZOE Facebook • JourneyQuest Facebook • Twitter • Instagram • Twitch • Discord • YouTube). Then encourage your friends and fellow JourneyQuest fans to do the same – these signups allow us to build enthusiasm for the campaign and communicate important updates.
Additionally, this year we are adding Quests to our campaign. We know that our fans are our best promoters and we want to celebrate this! For all backers at any level, we will add exclusive digital rewards to your pledge for every quest completed.  
 *Final Quest rewards are contingent upon Kickstarter campaign success.
Throughout the campaign, our livestream studio will host JOURNEYQUEST’S MOST VICTORIOUS CHARACTER, Fartherall’s epic bracket competition. Your votes throughout the week determine which character will arise victorious from their encounter.  Every Thursday at 6pm Pacific, we will announce the winners of the current week's matchups and immediately go into live polling for the next round's winners who will be announced at the end of the livestream. In the final week of the campaign, we will live stream a 5-hour campaign countdown and finale on Friday, July 12th. 
In addition to the game, we will host regular JourneyQuest watch parties complete with live commentary. Be sure to watch the "Upcoming Events" section above as well as our social media channels to make sure you don't miss a thing! 
SHIPPING
IMPORTANT: WE CHARGE FOR SHIPPING AFTER THE CAMPAIGN IN BACKERKIT, NOT IN KICKSTARTER.
Do NOT add shipping fees to your pledge now. 
Anything that you pledge over the cost of a reward level will not count as credit in BackerKit and will go directly to the JourneyQuest 4 production. Only give more than a pledge level if you want us to spend your additional contributions making JourneyQuest 4 even more awesome.
FULFILLMENT
The JourneyQuest 4 campaign will be fulfilled by our partners at Ship Naked, who maintain shipping depots in the United States, Canada, Germany, and Australia. Barring circumstances outside our control (like tariffs or trade wars) we will fulfill physical rewards from those depots.
 What will shipping cost in BackerKit?
 International Backers: expect to pay around $7.75 in BackerKit for base shipping on the $50 reward.
 United States Backers: expect to pay around $5.75 in BackerKit for base shipping on the $50 reward.
All shipping estimates are subject to change but will reflect the best market rates we can find when fulfillment begins.
JourneyQuest is created by an ever-growing team of talented and passionate actors, producers, crew, and support staff. Together, we've not only produced three seasons of JourneyQuest, but the ongoing Gamers series, Dark Dungeons, Demon Hunters, Attacking the Darkness, Strowlers, and much more. 
While our budgets are still a fraction of what Hollywood spends, doing it right means taking care of our cast and crew. Your support is what lets us keep telling original stories that you can't find anywhere else!
We are excited to shoot this season in British Columbia with talented Canadian director Joanna Gaskell, the co-creator of Standard Action.
Showrunner and writer Matt Vancil has once again lent his talents to a hilarious season four script and will oversee production.
Producer Tony Becerra returns to oversee production. He is joined by Mike Waverecan, a producer from M1 Films. M1 Films joins Zombie Orpheus for production of this season.
Social media coordinator Lee House will add his considerable talents to spreading the word about this campaign far and wide.
Of course, it wouldn't be JourneyQuest without our phenomenal cast. This season we're thrilled to bring back Christian Doyle (Perf), Alyssa Kay (Nara), Fran Kranz (Silver Tom), Kevin Pitman (Glorion), Brian Lewis (Carrow), Emille Shimkus (Wren), Jesse Lee Keeter (Rilk), Bob Sapp (Karn), Samara Lerman (Assassin), and many more! 
Zombie Orpheus Entertainment is pleased to team up with The Fantasy Network, a fan-supported, creator-distributed streaming service, to broadcast every JourneyQuest episode. In addition to works from Zombie Orpheus Entertainment, The Fantasy Network distributes original programming from Arrowstorm Entertainment (Mythica), The Forge Studios (The Rangers), Recursor.tv (Nina Unlocked) as well as numerous independent producers (AFK, One Hit Die, Ren the Girl With the Mark). While many titles are available on The Fantasy Network for free, your pledge of $10 or more unlocks one month of Fantasy Network subscriber-exclusive access.
We will be using BackerKit for pledge management after the campaign. A BackerKit survey will be sent to all backers several months after the Kickstarter campaign has completed. You will be able to update your address, add shipping fees and shop our pre-order store for any additional items from our back catalog that you would like to add to your shipment. 
Our shipping partners at Ship Naked will be handling warehousing and shipping for our campaign from their warehouse in the US. If we have a sufficient number of international backers, we will utilize their warehouses in Canada, Germany and Australia as well.
World of Fartherall is available for your storytelling and art under ZOE's new Shared Cinematic Universe License Agreement (the SCULA).
What does this mean?
It's like the Open Gaming License and Creative Commons had little license babies: it's an agreement that gives you permission to create, adapt, and release your own derivative works within the world of Fartherall!
Check out the web page for the full details, but the fast and dirty summary is that as long as you abide by the terms of the agreement, you have the freedom to create non-commercial AND commercial Fartherall derivatives. Make a roleplaying game. Shoot a web series. Create your art. Sell it if you want. Or give it away. It's your choice.
You, the fans, have made these works possible and this new agreement helps us give back. Come and play, you're invited!
Just remember to Share Alike, Transform (don't copy), provide accurate Attribution, and don't break the law.
Plus, if you want your creations to become a canon part of the world, we offer a path to make them official. And a cool seal. It's pretty awesome. 
ZOE and JourneyQuest are committed to cultivating healthy, inclusive communities where everyone is welcome. We extend that mission to improving representation both on screen and behind the camera. We're stronger when we work together to achieve common goals!
We welcome fans old and new to the community that will come together during this Kickstarter campaign and remind everyone that hate speech is not tolerated in this space. 
Our moderators are trained to help if you experience harassment in any ZOE-managed social arena. If we happen to miss it when it happens, please don't hesitate to reach out and let us know, so that we can take action to resolve the issue.
We are always happy to assist! If you have a question that was not answered here, please send us a message through Kickstarter or via the contact form at zombieorpheus.com.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
While we work hard to mitigate our risks, the unforeseen can always throw a curve ball. Sometimes we have to recast a role at the last minute. Sometimes we have to redo work in post if it doesn't meet our standards. Sometimes product gets delayed at the manufacturer. And any time international travel is involved, we have to be prepared to adapt and adjust with circumstances outside our control. But with a nine-year track record of crowdfunding success at Zombie Orpheus Entertainment, our reputation should speak for itself. 

Additionally, we now have excellent relationships with manufacturers, our fulfillment partners at Ship Naked, the team at BackerKit, and everyone else who's part of making sure that our campaigns are completed to your satisfaction. 

Our pledge to you is that we will always do our utmost to deliver on our commitment to excellence.

NOTE: We have budgeted for rewards and production based on current treaties, exchange rates, and tariffs. Given political volatility in the USA and elsewhere, we want to make special note that our plans may require significant revision should domestic or global turbulence affect the production of JourneyQuest Season Four.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

As you know, the global situation regarding COVID-19 continues to evolve on a daily basis. With that in mind, the JQ production team wanted to reach out and share detailed information about our plans.

campaign.story:
Fantasy Grounds Unity is the name of the upcoming version of our virtual tabletop software, Fantasy Grounds. It's been completely rebuilt from the ground up in Unity. Read on to find out what this all means and why we are excited for this project.
Fantasy Grounds is a popular system for playing a host of different roleplaying games online.  It is used by more than 130,000 gamers worldwide to connect and play popular games such as Dungeons and Dragons, Pathfinder, Savage Worlds, Call of Cthulhu, and more.  This type of program is commonly referred to as a virtual tabletop, or VTT, due to their ability to emulate various part of an RPG session in a digital form.
What makes Fantasy Grounds different than competitors is how we expose character sheets and automate large portions of gameplay specifically for each system we support.  This is done through rulesets.  Your experience playing Deadlands Reloaded will differ from D&D and will be unique to that environment, contain custom graphics, character sheets, and automation specific to that game system.  
One feature shared across most game systems is maps.  Some may use hexes while others use square grids and some may not use grids at all.  Facing is important in some and less so in others.  While FG has featured maps for many years, they have been primarily focused as reproductions of maps in existing adventure modules from our many licensed publishers. We believe that we can enhance these to provide dynamic line of sight, fog of war, and even map building support with painting and tiles.
What you get for backing this project will be a license for Fantasy Grounds Unity (or FGU). This new game engine has all the great features of current version of Fantasy Grounds (soon to be called Fantasy Grounds Classic) along with new enhanced features. 
Original Features Supported:
Multiplayer support for playing tabletop games of Dungeons & Dragons (2E, 3.5E, 4E and 5E), Pathfinder RPG 1, Pathfinder RPG 2, Starfinder.
Built-in content for D&D 3.5E, 5E and Pathfinder 1
Officially licensed add-on content available for D&D, D&D Classics (2E), Pathfinder, Starfinder, Savage Worlds, Call of Cthulhu, Basic Roleplaying, Castles & Crusades, Mutants & Masterminds, 13th Age, W.O.I.N., Traveller, and Rolemaster Classic
Generic system support through our CoreRPG ruleset
Brilliant Campaign Management
Integrated character sheets with lots of automation built in for playing and leveling (depending on ruleset and content owned)
Combat Tracking
3D dice
Fantasy Grounds Unity Enhanced Features Include:
64-bit support to allow for more content (quality and quantity)
Native support for Mac, Linux and Windows PC
Network lobby for easy hosting and joining of games (no port forwarding required)
Tile based map building
Enhanced Drawing Tools
Additional Dice Macros support
A new FGU only skin
Dynamic Line of Sight with enhanced toggle blockers
Paint with images, such as walls
Animated image effects
Backward compatibility with all existing campaigns and DLC from FGC
In addition to these features, we are now poised to add even greater functionality going forward. We have lots of ideas for new features and this rebuilt engine will make it easier for us reach those goals and deliver consistent updates for free. 
Tile based Map Building
Dynamic Line of Sight (LOS) and Fog of War (FOW)
Line of Sight - Doors and Terrain
Map Fx Layers
 New Grid Options
Advanced Dice Expression Support
We have already devoted over 4 years and 10,000 developer hours to this project. Any funds raised will help us push it over the edge and begin work on new features and functionality. If the project does exceptionally well, this may even allow us to add even more resources to the team.
We have over 1200 existing DLC and add-ons. Our goal is to prioritize these by popularity and work on enhancing as many of these as we can. Without enhancements, they will continue to function as they always have in Fantasy Grounds Classic. You will be able to add dynamic line of sight to maps and begin using the new features straight away. As we work through this large back catalog of DLC, we will do all the enhancement and upgrade work for you so you can just load it up and begin using the advanced features without having to define any Line of Sight blockers yourself. 
Link: www.fantasygrounds.com
Great! We anticipate that a large number of our backers will already be fans and users of our software. For you, we have added discounted Upgrade tiers available to get you up and running on the new engine as soon as possible. A lot of the time spent building the new engine was devoted towards making sure that everything you've already bought or created will continue to work in FGU. The only difference is that now you will be able to further enhance them.
Over time, we will begin going through older products and enhancing them for you. Just look for the Update Available button to light up and stay tuned to our newsletter for regular updates on which products have been newly Enhanced. 
Which Upgrade option do I choose?
If you bought your 1-time purchase license in 2018 or 2019, then pick the Rookie Upgrade for the license type you own: Standard or Ultimate. 
If you bought your 1-time purchase license before 2018, then choose the Veteran Upgrade for the license type you own: Standard or Ultimate.
If you are on a subscription, then you will be able to subscribe to the new version once it is released on the store. If you want Beta or Alpha access, then you would need to get a Newcomer tier option on the Kickstarter. 
How do I upgrade multiple license keys?
If your account has multiple license keys, it is possible that some of them are newer and some are older. Pick the tier that best fits your main license key that you personally use and then increase your pledge level for each additional license you have based on the age of that license.  Our survey system and fulfillment will allow some corrections there later on and we can always help on a case-by-case basis through our support email at the time of fulfillment.
Do I need to pay a subscription going forward?
Our newcomer tiers are 1-time purchase licenses for Fantasy Grounds Unity. No further subscription is required. If you had a subscription to Fantasy Grounds Classic, you may want to maintain that as long as you want to continue using that version. 
Yes, Fantasy Grounds Classic will remain a viable product for many years to come. While the data is backward compatible, we chose to separate the data paths for FGU and FG Classic so that changes to one won't be reflected in the other. You can copy campaigns over to FGU to try things out there and maintain your original copy back on Fantasy Grounds Classic. 
Over time, we expect most users will migrate fully to FGU.
Do I get access to Fantasy Grounds Classic if I buy Fantasy Grounds Unity?
No. If you already have a license or subscription, then you can continue to use that. The licenses will be different even though they share the same add-ons. 
Standard licenses can host or play in a game with other licensed users. An Ultimate license allows the GM to host a game for any number of players and those players can use a free Demo license of Fantasy Grounds. Initial copies will go out to backers only, but we will try to  send out the demo license links to backers at some point prior to launch so those can be shared with players for your game.
We have over 1200 DLC items available -- an entire gaming bookstore worth of games. It's too much to feature in the Kickstarter, but we have a select list of bundles below that you can choose from when we send out the backer surveys. Just increase your pledge amount for the add-ons you want from the list below. 
Also -- Anything you already own on your account at fantasygrounds.com will continue to work with FGU, so you won't have to re-buy any of those. In fact, you can go shopping at fantasygrounds.com if you see anything on sale there during or after the Kickstarter and those items will unlock automatically for your account once you gain access to FGU during the Alpha or Beta.
What if I bought my add-ons from Steam?
You will be able to use those in both versions: Fantasy Grounds Classic and Fantasy Grounds Unity. Our system will know what purchases you have made from either location. 
*Note: We have some unknowns about how the Steam Store will reflect purchases across the two versions of Fantasy Grounds. If you bought bundle items on Fantasy Grounds Classic, you may need to buy new additions to the bundle there instead of on the new FGU store page on Steam.

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Most of the major hurdles have been blasted away at this stage, but we still have a few issues that we are working to squash before we launch the Alpha or Beta version of the software. Depending on how long those take, the dates could shift. 

Our team has been testing and developing on Windows PCs. We make notes on things that we know we need to check into for Mac and Linux support but we have not yet attempted builds on those platforms. It is possible and expected that there will be a delay between releasing versions for Windows PC and Mac and Linux. In the worst case scenario, Windows PC users may complete the entire Alpha and Beta process before the Alpha and Beta process begins for other platforms. 

We will lock down the FGU Alpha Launch Party by the start of June. If there are significant delays in getting you access to the Alpha, we will still have some hands-on stuff for you at the event but we may delay access to the Alpha keys until a later date. Backers at that level will still get access before Beta users. 

We want to get the product into your hands as quickly as possible.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
